quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: If you're in a fast-growing company or a shrinking company, look there, don't look at trying to fight the natural evolution. I was just trying to prove a point and to illustrate that teams change.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: It would be highly convenient if we could just focus on building products that people love and getting product market fit, talking to customers. But the reality is we're humans together and there's a lot of opportunity to build companies that delight people where they're excited to be included in decision-making about how the organization grows and changes or shrinks.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: We rolled these whiteboards out and it had the team structure with everyone's names on it. It had the name of the team, the mission of the team, how many open slots for hiring across all of these different teams. And people were invited to look, give feedback. They identified mistakes that we had in the design.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: Reteaming is hard. Reorgs are hard. You can't lump them all into one thing with, oh, it's all great all the time. No, it's not. But we need to focus there. We got to focus on this people layer because reteaming is inevitable. We might as well get better at it because we're going to have to deal with it.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: Start a new team off to the side, a beneficial silo, give that team process freedom, great for catalyzing new product lines within your existing company. Also great for emergencies and they just happen anyway if we have incidents and people have to come together, solve an incident and then go back to their teams.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: When you're working on an existing product line, you get this cadence and it can become a mature cadence. But when you're working on something new, you need faster iteration loops. And our founders knew that need. So it was a privilege and I was delighted to be part of this other team.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: Tell other people not to disturb this team. That's key. And hearing it from a leader is really, really important. No, you're not going to pull them into something else. They're working on this other thing. So people need to shed their skin of the other things that they're working on.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: Switching is tied to learning and development and fulfillment. It could be that you want to work with other people. Tuckman's model, he forgot the phase called stagnating. Sometimes it feels like we're in a team for too long. We're tired of working with these people. We want a little variety.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: Switching also helps build that knowledge redundancy in your company. So if someone leaves, they don't leave with all the information in their head. We had that. At that first startup Expertcity, we had some single owners of systems and when they left, it just becomes a challenge and a setback.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: The company of today is not the company it was a year ago. The people turn over and change, what we work on turns over and change. The whole world and industry and global events change and put different pressures on us. So nothing lasts. Appreciate it when you're on a team and you love it and it's amazing because these are our lives.

quotes.speaker: Heidi Helfand
quotes.text: There's a book by William Bridges called Transitions. He talks about endings, neutral zone, and new beginning. Once I learned about that transition framework, going through any subsequent changes myself became a lot easier to grasp and it really kind of makes changes in any part of your life.

takeaways: Reteaming is inevitable whether your company is growing or shrinking - fighting the natural evolution of teams is counterproductive, so invest in getting better at managing change
The isolation pattern (beneficial silos) with process freedom is a proven way to catalyze innovation - protect the team from disruption and give them faster iteration loops
Transparent reorgs using techniques like whiteboard reteaming create better outcomes - involving people in organizational design decisions catches errors and builds ownership
Regular pair switching builds knowledge redundancy that creates organizational resilience - single owners of systems create dangerous fragility
Nothing lasts in organizations - appreciate great team experiences while they exist, because companies go through lifecycle stages that inevitably transform the dynamics

contrarian_candidates.why: Advocates for beneficial silos - directly challenges the popular wisdom that all silos must be broken down for collaboration
Argues Tuckman's famous team model is missing a 'stagnating' phase - challenges the assumption that stable teams always perform well
